title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: The upshot then is, Christopher,  that you would rather have what Eldon, Canning, Wel- Ungton, Liverpool, Peel, Eobinson, and Huskisson agree in considering the most practically pradent thing, than what any one of them thinks the thing most in unison with the dictates of absolute or abstract wisdom.

title: A summer's jaunt across the water.
author: Smith, J. Jay
snippet: Our John Bull sportsman, at dinner, gave us a specimen of the antipathy of his nation to the French ; among other anecdotes  he declared that he was invited to shoot with some gentlemen  near Paris; but what was his astonishment on arriving at the ground, to find the party dressed en chasse, with red jackets, and with cross-bows, to shoot frogs, at a few feet distance  ! The national feelings of the English break out at every opportunity against the Irish and French ; probably the same remark would hold good as to the Americans on proper ■ occasions ; one or two of our passengers, however, exhibited more knowledge of our country than is usual; Webster, Guizot, and Peel, are looked upon as the three men of the three nations, on whom the destinies of each, for good or for evil, are principally dependent.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: This is a knoll onthe adjoining farm of Peel, covered with some tallold ashes, beneath whose shade much of his poetrywas penned, and where at eventide he went out tomeditate.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: One day after lunch, at which theywere joined by Mr Laidlaw, the mighty tenant ofPeel, the three went out on horseback, taking theroad across the water.

title: Reminiscences of Yarrow. Edited and annotated by ... Professor Veitch, LL.D. Illustrated by Tom Scott ... Second edition
author: Russell, James
snippet: It was thus with Peel and Ashiestiel; and SirWalter Scott—who, though himself an Episcopalian, had great reverence for old Presbyterianpractices—liked nothing better than these recurringservices.
